"If the individual indicates in any manner at any time prior to or during questioning, that he wishes to remain silent, the interrogation must cease. "
The--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, why doesn't it--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But I don't think that was the question.
The question, at least as I understood it, is that Miranda says you cannot admit a confession into evidence unless he has first waived it.

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Then it says, clearly, that even if the police and the prosecution testify he did waive it, even if they say he did, explicitly, still, if there's a long questioning, even then, the court should be very careful about admitting it.

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: Right.
But then--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And doesn't it flow from that a fortiori that if he doesn't admit it and all there is, is the long questioning that, there has been no waiver?

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --But here Mr. Thompkins answered a series of questions knowing--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: He answered three questions.

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
One, do you believe in God?
Yes.
Two, do you pray to God?
Three, have you asked God for forgiveness for shooting the boy?
Okay.
So, where -- where did he waive it?

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: He -- that's what the Federal courts have done on direct review -- this is what Cardwell did, and there are five or six circuits have found the answers to the questions themselves can be the best--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So, in this case, after 2 hours and 15 minutes when he gave the answers I just said, when did he waive his Miranda rights?

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --When he answered those questions, because the--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No, I think any then -- then Miranda is--

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --No, because--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --It says you can't admit the stuff after a long questioning unless he waives.
Obviously, he says something or there would be nothing to admit.

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --The -- that's what the Federal courts have done in applying Butler, because the words and actions of the person interrogated can give rise to the inference that the person has waived.
Where the person has taken action that's inconsistent with the exercise of his rights, it is proper to find waiver.
The -- this--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --May I ask, can you go back to page 14 in your reply brief?
"Once warnings have been given, the subsequent procedure is clear. "

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia

turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the question is whether during those two hours by not answering a -- a number of questions, did he indicate in any way that he wished to remain silent?

turn.text: Right.
That this -- so if you look at the implication analysis, did he make it clear that I don't want to participate in this interrogation?
Detective Helgert's testimony--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then it says that any -- in any manner that he wished to remain silent.
And until the 2 hours and a half later when he did answer the three questions, that's pretty -- it's at least arguable that his silence indicated he wished to remain silent.

turn.speaker: b_eric_restuccia
turn.label: Mr. B. Eric Restuccia
turn.text: --Well, what happens, though, in Davis, this Court made clear for the purpose of invocation, that the invocation has to be unambiguous because the police have to know when they have to cut off their questioning.

Detective Helgert believed, through his limited responses, the give and take of part of this interview, that he was a willing participant in the interview.
This is the factual record that was established by the State courts.
